sections.content: The Challenge: Ship Multi-Tenant Platform in 9 Months

Co-led product strategy for multi-tenant telehealth platform build from concept to production. The goal: launch with real paying patients, live prescriptions, and operational pharmacy fulfillment‚Äînot a prototype.
After leaving CompoundLive/Rugiet (acquired by ListenCo), I proposed building a next-generation telehealth platform incorporating everything I'd learned. The vision:

content: Multi-tenant SaaS architecture supporting multiple healthcare brands
Native AI capabilities for clinical documentation
Better clinical workflows learned from previous platforms
Flexible product configuration and billing models
HIPAA compliance and operational excellence from day one

sections.content: Conducted stakeholder research and user interviews with chronic migraine patients to validate business model:

content: Validated $499/year membership model with target patients
Interviewed doctors about clinical workflow needs
Researched competitor platforms to identify gaps
Analyzed pharmacy partner capabilities and state coverage
Evaluated regulatory requirements across 48 states

sections.content: Product judgment isn't about what you build; it's about what you *don't* build. I cut admin analytics and reporting features to zero to ensure we nailed the core patient/doctor workflows.

sections.title: Must-Have for Launch
content: Patient portal with account management
Doctor portal with consultation workflows
E-prescribing via DoseSpot integration
Pharmacy fulfillment with routing logic
Payment processing via PayTheory
Multi-tenant architecture with data isolation
HIPAA-compliant infrastructure

sections.title: Cut Scope (The 'No' List)
content: Advanced analytics and reporting dashboards
Marketing automation and email campaigns
Detailed financial reporting
A/B testing infrastructure
Mobile applications

sections.content: Strategic thinking: Coordinated 4 engineers + CTO through 12 two-week sprints with 95% on-time delivery.

content: Sprint planning with clear priorities and acceptance criteria
Daily standups to unblock engineering
Bi-weekly demos to stakeholders for feedback
Continuous prioritization adjustments based on learnings
Technical spec writing for complex integrations

sections.content: Made critical vendor decision: chose Choose Health over competitors for lab integration due to better API documentation, even though it was more expensive‚Äîthis decision saved 2+ weeks of integration time.
Soft launch with beta patients before full marketing push:

content: Recruited 25 beta patients for initial cohort
Monitored every prescription, consultation, and payment
Gathered feedback on user experience and clinical workflows
Fixed bugs and refined features based on real usage
Validated operational processes with pharmacy partners

sections.content: Official launch: August 4, 2025, with real paying patients rather than perfect features.

sections.content: Ruthless prioritization enabled aggressive timeline. By cutting nice-to-have features (analytics, marketing automation) and focusing on core patient/doctor workflows, we launched 3 months earlier. Shipping with real paying patients validated product-market fit and operational readiness better than any internal testing could. The 95% on-time delivery rate came from clear priorities, detailed specs, and daily communication.
